qas.question: What is the official name of code 127?
What was code 127 labeled as for the Teletype?
Why did Teletype have the code for "rubout"?

answers.text: to make it an ignored character

qas.question: What is the official name of an existing mark?
What was NUL named as for the Teletype?

plausible_answers.text: to make it an ignored character

qas.question: Why did teletype have extra spaces for "rubout"?
What happened to replacements of control codes?

plausible_answers.text: punching the all-ones bit pattern on top of an existing mark would obliterate it

qas.question: Why was standard code useful for paper tape?

context: Code 127 is officially named "<a0_0><b3_0>delete<b3_0/><a0_0/>" but the Teletype label was "<a1_0><b4_0>rubout<b4_0/><a1_0/>". Since the original standard did not give detailed interpretation for most control codes, interpretations of this code varied. The original Teletype meaning, and the intent of the standard, was <a2_0><b5_0>to make it an ignored character<b5_0/><a2_0/>, the same as NUL (all zeroes). This was useful specifically for paper tape, because <b7_0>punching the all-ones bit pattern on top of an existing mark would obliterate it<b7_0/>. Tapes designed to be "hand edited" could even be produced with spaces of extra NULs (blank tape) so that a block of characters could be "rubbed out" and then replacements <b6_0>put into the empty space<b6_0/>.
